text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 15th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why the man takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor on rainy days.
Let's break down the problem step by step.
First, let's understand his usual routine.
Every morning, he lives on the 15th floor and takes the elevator down to the ground floor (which is the 1st floor) to go to work.
So, he's going from 15th to 1st floor in the morning.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to reach his apartment on the 15th floor.
So, in the evening, he goes from the ground floor (1st) to the 10th floor by elevator and then walks up 5 floors.
Now, on rainy days, he changes his routine.
Instead of taking the elevator to the 10th floor and walking up, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.
So, on rainy days, he goes from the ground floor directly to the 15th floor without getting off at the 10th.
I need to figure out why this change happens on rainy days.
Maybe there's a reason related to the elevator's behavior or the building's structure.
Let me think about possible scenarios.
One possibility is that the elevator has a limit to how high it can go.
Maybe on rainy days, the elevator doesn't go above a certain floor, like the 10th floor.
So, if he tries to go higher, it stops at the 10th, forcing him to walk up.
But in this case, he's changing his routine, so maybe the elevator is malfunctioning or has a restriction on rainy days.
Alternatively, perhaps the building has different elevator services on rainy days.
Maybe the main elevator is out of service, so he has to use a different one that only goes up to the 10th floor.
But then, why would he take the main elevator if it's not working? That doesn't quite make sense.
Another angle is that the elevator's speed or efficiency changes on rainy days.
Maybe the elevator is slower, so going all the way up would take too long.
But he's going to work every morning, so maybe the time isn't the main issue.
Wait, maybe it's about the weather affecting his commute.
On rainy days, walking up the stairs might be slippery or wet, making it dangerous.
So, he prefers to take the elevator all the way up instead of walking the five floors.
That seems plausible.
But the problem says he does this in the evening when he returns from work.
So, he's going from the ground floor to the 15th floor on rainy days.
If walking up five floors is dangerous, he'd prefer not to do that.

But why didn't he do that before?

Perhaps the building's elevator system changes on rainy days.
Maybe the elevator is being serviced, and it's only going to the 10th floor, so he has to take it all the way up because that's the highest it goes.
Or perhaps the elevator is broken and he has to use a different one that goes higher.
Wait, another thought: maybe the building has different elevator banks.
In the evening, he uses a different elevator that only goes up to the 10th floor, so he takes that one, but on rainy days, he uses a different elevator that goes all the way up.
But that seems a bit far-fetched.
Alternatively, maybe the man is trying to save time or avoid walking on rainy days.
So, in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and walks up because it's quicker than waiting for the elevator to go higher.
But on rainy days, he doesn't want to walk, so he takes the elevator all the way up.
Wait, but why would he take the elevator to the 10th floor normally? Maybe the elevator is faster or more convenient up to the 10th floor, and walking up five floors is quicker or more direct.
So, on rainy days, he avoids walking because it's slippery, hence taking the elevator all the way.
Another angle: maybe the building's elevators have a maximum speed or time limit, so going higher takes longer.
On rainy days, he doesn't want to wait longer, so he takes the elevator all the way to avoid delays.
But I think the most logical reason is that on rainy days, walking up the stairs is unsafe, so he prefers to take the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.
Therefore, the answer is that on rainy days, he avoids walking up the stairs because it's slippery or wet, so he takes the elevator directly to his floor.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor on rainy days because walking up the stairs from the 10th to the 15th floor would be slippery and unsafe.
